story: I know it is the 2nd week of a New Year but I have been abstaining from alcohol and doing Dry January....everyone who knows me knows I am partial to a wee JD or numerous pints of lager.....the idea has just come to me whilst I am sat here with a cup of tea.  Cancer is one of the most common diseases that affects so many people each and every single day, I have lost loved ones with it, friends and family alike, I know how it feels to see loved ones suffering - if I can beat my target I will continue to abstain throughout February too.....again, anyone who knows me knows I would not cheat as this is too personal for me.  A quid here and a quid there can make all the difference, I know times are hard with COVID but Cancer Research needs us more than anything.....IF and I mean IF I fail, I will personally reimburse any monies that has been paid out of my own pocket - as it is the 2nd week, I have paid into the fundraiser already with what I would have spent in the supermarket on a few tins - thanks for reading xx

story:
On the 1st January we lost an amazing Husband, Father, Grandad, and Great-granddad - and a truly special friend to so many more.  

Whilst Stanley had battled ill-health for quite some time he was a true fighter - and gave us all many years of treasured memories. 

Sadly this day would always come far too soon. 

During these times restrictions mean that we are unable to gather today to say our final goodbyes and give Stanley the send off he truly deserves.   

Today as we celebrate his life - we are thankful that in 1992 he was given life changing heart surgery.  The help and support of the British Heart Foundation changed all our lives.  

In Stanley’s memory we would love to support the British Heart Foundation by raising funds to help and support other families during their difficult times.  

Please also feel free to leave your messages and memories of Stanley - these will be of comfort to all his family and friends.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

story:
My name’s Emma and I’m a chocoholic.

In a heartbeat. Change of heart. Heart to heart. Follow your heart. Eat your heart out! 

That last one is something I’m going to try and give the heave ho. Anyone who knows me will know there are some things I could give up in the blink of an eye (or indeed in a heartbeat!) but take my fizzy pop and chocs away!? How dare you!

I’ve got my fair share of people I could dedicate this, for me, momentous effort, to, but I think it’s best done with the family and friends I’m lucky enough to still have, in mind. The heart is something we all have in common and we only get one. So to raise money, and put less strain on mine, I’ve decided to give up my beloved sugar rush. Now I apologise in advance to any who may encounter me in the first days of this as I’d imagine I’ll be even less tolerable than usual! That’s my piece, below is what BHF have to say.. 

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge the British Heart Foundation has faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. 

I am obsessed with chocolate, much preferring it to chewy sweets and I think I will find this quite a challenge. But obviously, going without chocolate is nothing compared to those living with heart and circulatory diseases - diabetes, angina, strokes, heart failure. There's 7.6 million people in the UK doing much harder stuff than not eating chocolate every day for the sake of their health.

BHF research can help them. So if you can, please chuck me a couple of quid as I get progressively grumpier in March, and my teeth thank me for it...!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Just Giving page.

It's been a tricky year and feels like a Groundhog day of zoom meetings, emails and homeschooling. We're fortunate that we have a strong business and our lovely colleagues to lean on, but whilst we've been busy working hard, our dogs are feeling a bit neglected, and in truth so are our exercise regimes! So we decided we wanted to get up from our desks to help support this fantastic charity - and our own furry, four-legged friends.

So, we've come up with a cunning plan to raise money for Guide Dogs for the Blind by jointly dog walking 1000kms, or the broad equivalent of Lands’ End to John O'Groats...in 10 weeks.

We've provided stuffed toy dog companions for colleagues without dogs but with little kiddies to tempt them out. For colleagues without kids or dogs they can borrow dogs; or walk with their dog-owning support bubbles. There's no excuse not to get out into the winter air and putting the kilometres in!

And you can help us by donating anything you can for this fabulous charity and helping us reach our goal of £1/kilometre. Anything from £1/100kms, to £1/km, everything is welcome and appreciated! And just think, when it's cold, dark and miserable out there it's us that will be out walking whilst you're tucked up warm and dry... but our dogs will thank you for it, and so will we.

story:
As a group of 8 hotel managers we have raised the competition between ourselves and our ROM to be the biggest loser and lose the most amount of excess lockdown weight.

Involved in this challenge is James Hulme, Paul Banks, Simon Nisbet, Laura Esposito, Stephen Ablitt, Filippo Landoni, Chand Chouhan, Kwame Johnson, Maria Klug and we hope to raise a minimum of £900 between us.

Every 2 weeks we have a weigh in to see how we are doing. Not only is this to support us in better health physically and mentally but we would love to raise some money doing this for a great cause.

Great Ormond Street Hospital supports seriously ill children from all over the UK. Every day 619 children and young people arrive at GOSH to receive care and life saving treatments to ensure they can continue to lead healthy lives. Since 2012, Premier Inn and Restaurants have been proud partners of Great Ormond Street Hospital Charity and we know our passionate teams have taken part in many brilliant fundraising events as well as volunteering at national events around the country and at the hospital.During these uncertain times our teams continue to achieve incredible things, challenging themselves to conquer their Everest and take care of their wellbeing. We are looking to continue the fantastic fundraising achieved through our partnership by supporting our teams in their creative and dedicated ways of personal achievement. We are #innthistogether and together, we can continue our incredible work.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

10 years ago Mum had Breast Cancer, during lockdown in the summer of 2020 she became ill and after several tests it was found she has Secondary Breast Cancer, which is not curable.  Mum is a fighter and is currently doing well, but has been isolating since February 2020 so to give her something to take her mind off her illness she started knitting toys, hats and gloves for children which I sold for her via Facebook at Christmas time.  

As we'd like to reach our target, I am making face masks and asking for donations.

Cancer affects so many people and their families, and it's been so much harder during this pandemic, which makes it even more important that we continue raising awareness and funds so the research into new drugs and treatments can be found.  Mum is being looked after really well by her consultant and the team of nurses both at the hospital and in the community and we both would like to think that every cancer patient can have that care if the funds are available.

Mum and I would like to say a very big Thank you to all who have donated so far.  

Take care and Keep safe

I am incredibly proud to work for this amazing charity. Working for Marie Curie has always been something I’ve wanted to do for many years. Eventually I took the plunge, got selected for an interview and got the job!

I now work nights providing relief to families looking after their loved ones with terminal illnesses and providing support to the patient throughout the night. It can be a very tough job at times, turning up to a patients house for your night sit on Christmas Eve to be told the patient has just passed and seeing the family grieving on what should be a happy occasion really hits home. RNLI lifeboats in Scotland protect hundreds of communities with a 24-hour search and rescue service. Our volunteer crews rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from. 
Scotlands unrivalled coasts and waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.
Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 46 of the lifeboat stations in Scotland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. story:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page.
Since the pandemic began in early 2020 we have had to cancel events and have been unable to be out and about talking to you about the work of the RNLI at our street and event collections in and around Honley and Brockholes.
This is having a huge effect on donations, which is why we are coming out to our friends, families and supporters virtually to ask for your help - as a charity, the RNLI relies on donations from you, the general public and without your support we wouldn't be able to continue saving lives at sea.
The Covid-19 pandemic has brought a new risk to our volunteers that we never could have predicted or imagined but our brave and courageous crew members continue to risk their lives to save others.
We hope that you can support us by donating on our page - we look forward to seeing you soon, stay safe.


Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all Yorkshire and the North East lifeboat stations is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. Since the Covid-19 pandemic, we havent been able to fundraise as normal to keep our lifeboats afloat but many of our stations have been busier than ever. Your donation to this page will help support the running of our 19 stations in Yorkshire and the North East; Amble, Berwick upon Tweed, Blyth, Bridlington, Craster, Cullercoats, Filey, Flamborough, Hartlepool, Humber, Newbiggin, Redcar, Scarborough, Seahouses, Staithes and Runswick, Sunderland, Tynemouth, Whitby and Withernsea

story:
The RNLI has been operating at full capacity since the start of lockdown. Our service has been rescuing people throughout the Coronavirus pandemic and our heroic crews commitment to saving lives has not stopped. Unfortunately, our ability to raise funds has been limited.

The coasts of Wales and North West England are popular tourist destinations for millions of holidaymakers from the Midlands and we want to keep those coasts a safe place for everyone to visit.

The average lifeboat station in Wales, North West England and Isle of Man costs £159,000 a year to run and we are going to have a significant shortfall in income due to the Coronavirus.

We are asking all our friends and communities to donate what they can to keep us running.

When you and your loved visit the coast, we will always be there to keep you safe, on our watch, there will be no preventable deaths on British coasts.

Please help us fulfil that mission.

story:
Thank you for supporting me to take part in Walk In Her Shoes! 

Every day thousands of women and girls, all over the world, have no choice but to walk many miles to fetch water for their families. Water that is often dirty.

Their daily routine deprives them of the chance to have an education, a job, and traps them in a cycle of poverty.

Your support can help build wells and water pumps closer to rural communities so that women and girls dont have to spend their days walking for water, and can plan for a better future.

For more information please visit www.careinternational.org.uk where their website is kept up-to-date regularly.
